author: JT
title: Jordan River Foundation empowers 157 beneficiaries with enhanced skills to enter labour market | Jordan Times
text:
AMMAN — The Jordan River Foundation (JRF) on Thursday said it has enabled 157 beneficiaries under the project “Strengthening the capacity of Syrian refugees for self-reliance, improving livelihoods and financial integration”, implemented in partnership with UNHCR.
The JRF said in a statement that it honoured the beneficiaries of the project after completing a set of technical trainings provided by 36 service providers from the JRF’s strategic partners, the Jordan News Agency, Petra, reported.
The technical training was in digital marketing, website design, and audio production and metallurgy, translation skills for micro project hub beneficiaries, as well as special training in electricity and hybrid vehicle maintenance, personal care and beauty skills which targeted career networking hub beneficiaries.
The project guaranteed beneficiaries a grant to establish their own project within specific areas associated with training. A number of them would also be employed in private companies in the framework of the JRF’s partnership and agreements with the private sector.
JRF said that an honorary ceremony was organised on the sidelines of the project for the service provider partners, in appreciation of their efforts in empowering the people and families benefittng from the project, which include the Volt Academy, Luminus Technical University College, Laval Academy, Jordan Engineers Association and Dot Jordan.
In total, the project targeted approximately 660 Jordanian families and Syrian refugees in seven governorates: Amman, Irbid, Ajloun, Mafraq, Tafila, Maan and Aqaba, to boost the income level of the targeted families by providing them with training courses that enable them to develop their professional and entrepreneurial capabilities, in addition to providing guidance and guidance services.

author: Terry McKiernan
title: Settlement reached in abuse trial
text:
VANCOUVER (CANADA)
The Catholic Register - Archdiocese of Toronto, Ontario, Canada
February 22, 2024
The Archdiocese of Vancouver has reached a settlement with a man who was sexually assaulted by a priest and a teacher at Holy Trinity Parish in North Vancouver in the 1970s.
The settlement was reached during the civil trial at B.C. Supreme Court in New Westminster, where the plaintiff, “John Doe,” described abuse by Fr. John Kilty and teacher Raymond Clavin.
Before the trial began, the Archdiocese acknowledged the abuse occurred but denied being negligent as an organization.
At John Doe’s request, the terms of the settlement are not being disclosed.
In a statement, the Archdiocese said, “No words of regret can fully repair the profound horror of the past and the pain endured by victims/survivors of abuse.” It said Archbishop J. Michael Miller extended “heartfelt sorrow to the plaintiff and all victims of abuse on behalf of the Catholic community.”
Beginning in late 2018, the Archdiocese of Vancouver conducted a review of historic files relating to sexual abuse by clergy. The goal of that review, said the statement, “was to reach and help more survivors, address past wrongs and to show more transparency.” The Archdiocese came forward with the publication of names and photos of priests known to have abused children.
“We hope the publicity from this case will help give any other victims/survivors the confidence to come forward and get the help they deserve.”
The Archdiocese encouraged anyone who has been a victim of Church-related abuse to come forward, no matter how long ago the abuse may have occurred. It said an independent social worker is available by calling (604) 363-7338 or 1-800-968-3146.
“They will compassionately listen to you and outline some possible options for care. We understand how much courage it takes to report your experience, and we sincerely hope that every victim/survivor will consider coming forward.”

title: Alimentare lo spettacolo che si prende gioco dell'ossessione per la cucina gourmet
text:

author: Jeremy Chunn
title: Australia HR Awards 2024: Highlights from a night of excellence | HRD Australia
text:
'This is HR's night, they deserve recognition'
BY Jeremy Chunn 20 Sep 2024 Share HR professionals from across Australia filled the ballroom at the Fullerton Hotel in the Sydney CBD last week for the Australian HR Awards 2024.
The gala event recognised the best talent in the Australian human resources profession over the past year.
Winners were named across 20 categories, including Best Graduate Development Program, Best Use of Technology, Best Recruitment Campaign and, of course, Best HR Director of the Year.
Attendees filed out towards midnight agreeing the evening was a spectacular success.
Peter Stewart, CEO of disability service provider estara, accepted the award for Australian HR Campion of the Year, sponsored by software provider Martian Logic.
“We are in the people business,” he told HRD. “Championing the amazing work our 700 people do on a day-in, day-out basis just feeds my soul.”
HR awards: ‘They deserve recognition’ As Australians measure their pennies at supermarket checkouts, Coles Group HR director Kris Webb – awarded HR Director of the Year – said a highlight of 2024 was getting the right work hours for her team of 125,000 workers.
“Communicating that to 900 stores across the country is a huge piece of work,” Webb said. “If we have the right people in stores, our customers are happier.”
Most Read Revealed: Winners of the Australian HR Awards for 2024 Court allows 15-year-delayed sexual harassment case to proceed against employer 'Serious misconduct': how to handle bad behaviour in the C-suite HR deserves the benefit of sophisticated tools, said Anwar Khalil, the CEO of headline sponsor and HR technology provider Martian Logic.
“HR is not admin, it is about providing human resources solutions,” he said. “Professionals like the ones recognised tonight at these awards provide solutions and benefit companies. This is a huge task.”
Khalil summed up the awards night as the band played on: “This is HR’s night. They deserve recognition. It’s a beautiful thing, very powerful.”
HR Manager of the Year for 2024 is Janani D’Silva, who heads the HR team at Capgemini Australia and New Zealand.
 “HR is a team sport,” she said. “There is no one person who stands out. It’s nice to be propped up by a huge group of colleagues.”
‘The awards mean a lot to us’ Attendees mingled and caught up with industry colleagues and counterparts over dinner between three awards announcement sessions, emceed by comedian Merrick Watts.
The Australian Financial Complaints Authority does fantastic work for people affected by scams and Sue Stone accepted the award for HR Team of the Year for an organisation with more than 1,000 employees.
“We have an incredible, hard-working team that really care about our employees,” she said, pointing to DEI, health and wellbeing and leave-enhancement programs. “Our people really respect and appreciate that.”
Sponsors also included Referoo and hubPass by hub.health, who supported categories such as Best Health and Wellbeing Program (hubPass by hub.health) and Best Recruitment Campaign (Referoo), among others.
“The awards mean a lot to us,” said Referoo co-founder and CEO Neil Rose. “It’s been a busy year. Technology is taking away a lot of the drudgery of HR and allowing people to really add value to the process.”
“People and culture is at the heart of what we do,” said Midnight Health CEO & Founder Nic Blair (Midnight Health brands include hubPass by hub.health). “Recognising the people who look after people is at the core of what we like to do as a business and why we support the awards.”
After the last trophy was handed out and closing remarks were delivered, the dancefloor quickly filled with winners, nominees and happy HR advocates.
A fill list of this year’s winners can be found here . Congratulations, everybody – and see you next year!

author: Danielle Wiener-Bronner
title: Tyson CFO John Tyson arrested for DWI
text:
New York (CNN) — Tyson Foods suspended its CFO John R. Tyson after he was arrested Thursday on charges of DWI and careless driving. Tyson, the great grandson of the founder of the meat processing company, was previously arrested in 2022 on charges of public intoxication and criminal trespass .
The 34-year-old was booked early Thursday and has since been released, according to the Washington County, Arkansas, Detention Intake Report. His initial hearing is scheduled for Friday.
“We are aware that John Randal Tyson, Chief Financial Officer of Tyson Foods, was arrested for an alleged DWI,” the company said in a statement Thursday.
“Tyson Foods has suspended Mr. Tyson from his duties effective immediately and named Curt Calaway as interim Chief Financial Officer.”
Back in 2022, Tyson was charged after he allegedly wandered into the wrong home and fell asleep. News reports at the time said he was found asleep on a bed by a woman who lived there. She called the police, who then identified Tyson through his driver’s license. He reportedly later pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor charges related to the incident.
Tyson issued an apology during an analyst call in November 2022. “I’m embarrassed and I want to let you know that I take full responsibility for my actions,” he said at the time. “I also want to apologize to our investors as I have to our employees.”
During that same call, Tyson Foods CEO Donnie King said that the company was taking the incident seriously through its “corporate governance process.”
